posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS320
posts.body: Hello, my name is Joe and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 320 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 320 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: CS320 is moderately difficult. Not too easy, not too bad, but expect to commit a decent amount of hours each week for the psets.
CS320 wasn't that bad, the course covers the OCaml language, which is very similar to Java. The problem sets which involve theory and coding aren't bad, but take time.

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS330
posts.body: Hello, my name is Joe and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 330 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 330 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: CS330 is the the hardest class i took at BU.
CS330 wasn't that bad.

CS 330 goes in depth with data structures and algorithms, such as graphs, BFS, DFS, Djikstra's, greedy, dynamic programming, etc... There will be coding and written parts on the HW that will be extremely time-consuming. You will want to put the most effort into this class.

posts.title: Clarifying time complexity of this algorithm

comments.comment: Should be O(n)
I would that a look specifically at lecture 7 slide 78.
The time complexity would be O(n) because we are traversing through each element at most once.

posts.title: BFS vs DFS
posts.body: When should I use BFS over DFS in graph problems?

comments.comment: Use BFS to find shortest path
BFS searches adjacent nodes, so it will find the shortest path quicker, since we will run out of nodes to add to the queue sooner for that path.
DFS is better for decision based problems and is quicker than BFS, since it doesn't search all neighbors.

posts.title: Djikstra's algorithm
posts.body: Could someone explain Djikstra's algorithm in simple terms?

comments.comment: Simply put, Dijkstra's algorithm allows us to find the shortest path between any two vertices of a graph.

posts.title: Stack vs Queue
posts.body: How do I decide when to use a stack vs queue?

comments.comment: stack is a first in first out data structure (FIFO).
A queue is a last in first out data structure (LIFO).
a stack and queue are implemented the same way in python

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS411
posts.body: Hello, my name is Adam and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 411 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 411 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: CS411 is the the easiest cs class i've ever taken.
It is very straightforward. You learn about the software development life cycle, and do a semester long group project.

posts.title: Project Ideas
posts.body: Could anyone who has taken this class before describe their projects?

comments.comment: We made a spotify to apple music converter.
We created a mobile app that returns a list of recommended nearby stores based on what items you need.
We created a course availability web app for BU students using web scrapers and Python.

posts.title: 411 Final
posts.body: How should I prepare for the 411 Final

comments.comment: I believe it's cumulative, so review all lectures slides from Piazza.
It focuses on second half of the course. I would focus on the SDLC.

posts.title: Midterm 1
posts.body: How should I prepare for Midterm 1?

comments.comment: Review the differences between software development processes.
Make sure you know all of the basic git commands like push, pull, rebase, commit.
Understand tech stacks well, like databases, frontend, backend..

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS412
posts.body: Hello, my name is Joe and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 412 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 412 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: CS412 is both easy and fun, structured similarly to 411, but delving into more of the specifics of web development.

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS210
posts.body: Hello, my name is Brandon and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 210 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 210 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: 210 is definitely moderately difficult, but there is a lot of time given to understand the material.
When I took it, there were 5 problem sets with sufficient time in between to complete them. Definitely utilize office hours for help on the homework.
210 is divided into two parts. The first half focuses on Linux/Unix. The second half delves deep into the von Neumann architecture, and towards the end, the course touches on C programming.

posts.title: Calculator Assignment
posts.body: Any tips for the Calculator Assignment?

comments.comment: Start early.
Don't start it last minute. Go to office hours if you can. It's not something you can finish in one day, so don't wait.

posts.title: What is 'malloc'?
posts.body: Could someone please explain what 'malloc' is in C?

comments.comment: Malloc stands for memory allocation and is a C library function that allocates memory from the heap. Malloc returns a pointer that is used to access the memory that was allocated.
The general syntax of 'malloc' is ptr = (cast-type*) malloc(byte-size).
An example to add on would be 'ptr = (int*) malloc(100 * sizeof(int));', which allocates 400 bytes of memory.

posts.title: Midterm Format
posts.body: What is the format of the midterms?

comments.comment: It should be formatted just like the practice midterm that was provided.

posts.title: Recursion explanation needed
posts.body: Could someone please explain recursion in simple terms?

comments.comment: Recursion is the process in which a function calls itself either directly or indirectly to solve the problem.
To add on, recursion means that we are creating smaller subproblems and using all of the solutions to the smaller subproblems to generate a result.

posts.title: Difficulty of CS 111
posts.body: Hello, I am transferring to CS major and I was wondering anyone could share their experiences with the class and its overall difficulty?

comments.comment: CS111 is probably one of the easiest CS courses at BU. I would recommend taking CS131 with it since that class is more time consuming and challenging for most people.
I would say it's relatively difficult with no experience but you have plenty of resources available to use! Make sure to go to office hours!
The course is both very straightforward and interesting.

posts.title: List vs Tuple
posts.body: What is the difference between a list and a tuple?

comments.comment: Tuples and immutable, while lists are mutuable.
To add on, this immutable means that tuples cannot be changed, while lists can be modified.
I think it's important to mention that tuples are more efficient in terms of memory than lists.

posts.title: Quick Question on List Comprehension
posts.body: What is the purpose of list comprehension?

comments.comment: List comprehension simply involves a more concise syntax when creating new lists based on an existing list's values.

posts.title: Multiple Inheritance
posts.body: How does multiple inheritance in Python work and what is its result?

comments.comment: To add on, multiple inheritance can be situationally useful in creating more flexible design, but it significantly increases the ambiguity and complexity of the language. Languages like Java and C# that do not offer MI generally have cleaner code as a result.

Defining a class in Python with multiple inheritances is essentially the same process as with single inheritance. For example, in 'class Child(Parent1, Parent2)', the child inherits features from both Parent1 and Parent2.
Multiple inheritance means that less code needs to be written, however, the code is more difficult to maintain in the long run.

posts.title: CS112 vs CS111
posts.body: Hello, my name is Josh and I am a rising sophomore planning to take CS 112 in the fall. How does the class compare to CS111? To put it into context, I did not struggle at all in CS111.

comments.comment: It's a pretty big step up from 111 based on personal experience. The homework will take around 5-15 hours/week depending on the material.
112 is not easy but very important as it covers basic data structures. It can be considered a weed out course, so do your absolutely best.
It's much more difficult.

posts.title: Midterm Time Complexity
posts.body: Will we need to know time complexity for the midterm?

comments.comment: Make sure to know the time complexities of all of the sorting algorithms as well as be ready to provide the run time complexity of a given function.

posts.title: Immutable String
posts.body: Why is string immutable in Java?

comments.comment: One reason is security, so that sensitive information such as usernames or passwords cannot be changed.
Another reason is synchronization or concurrency---being immutable also means that String is thread safe which resolves issues with synchronization.
Another reason is caching. The compiler recognizes that only one string object is needed, when we have two objects with the same value.

posts.title: Recursion vs iteration
posts.body: Can I just use iteration instead of recursion for the homework?

comments.comment: It states in the problem that they want the iterative solution.
Reach out to the professor.

posts.title: Stack vs Queue
posts.body: How do I decide when to use a stack vs queue?

comments.comment: Use a stack when you want to reverse the order of items that you added, and use a queue when you want to maintain the order of items that you added
Stack is a first in first out data structure (FIFO), while queue is a last in first out data structure(LIFO).

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS131
posts.body: Hello, my name is Jeff and I am a freshman planning to take CS 131 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 111, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 131 and its difficulty compared to 111. Thanks!

comments.comment: 131 is pretty difficult , although it is curved pretty heavily.
131 is primarily proofs and discrete math

posts.title: Simplification Rule
posts.body: With the simplification rule of inference, would (not q and (p and r)) become (not q), (p and r), or just one of them?

comments.comment: Either one should work.

posts.title: Tips on Problem 1
posts.body: Any tips for starting the first problem on HW2?

comments.comment: Consider how you could incorporate the XOR operator into this problem.

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS132
posts.body: Hello, my name is Jake and I am a rising junior planning to take CS 132 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 132 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: CS 132 is essentially linear algebra with a bit of coding in python. It would be a good idea to brush up on Python concepts and expect a lot of math.

About the same amount of material as 131, but the material is much easier to comprehend. There are around 15 problems per problem set, with most of it being written and a small portion being coding/computational. Expect to spend at least 5 hours/week on problem sets.
The first few weeks of 132 cover parts of 131.

posts.title: 132 Curved?
posts.body: Is there a generous curve for this class?

comments.comment: It's not very generous. There might be a slight curve but the average is generally around a B. In my experience, the professor didn't curve it much above the average.
Check lecture 7 slide 78
I think it's O(n) because we are traversing through each element at most once.

posts.title: Lecture Notes?
posts.body: Where can I find the lecture notes for this class?

comments.comment: Here is the link for the online lecture notes for the current professor that teaches 132 (Crovella): https://mcrovella.github.io/CS132-Geometric-Algorithms/landing-page.html

posts.title: Question about Difficulty of Class CS237
posts.body: Hello, my name is Joe and I am a rising sophomore planning to take CS 237 next semester. In context, I struggled with CS 112 and CS 131, and I was wondering if anyone could share experiences with CS 237 and its difficulty compared to previous courses. Thanks!

comments.comment: The class is homework-heavy, but grading usually generous. There are programming assignments on top of the written assignments, but nothing terrible if you did well in CS 111.
In advance, it might be helpful to take a look at MIT's online intro to probability course.
If you understand probability and statistics well, this class should be pretty easy.

posts.title: Confusion on Monty Hall
posts.body: I'm still confused on the Monty Hall problem. Could someone please elaborate?

comments.comment: The key takeaway from the Monty Hall problem is that decisions are heavily influenced by previous decisions.

In an example with 3 doors, we have a 2/3 of selecting a wrong door and 1/3 chance of choosing the right door. There is a 2/3 chance that we pick the wrong door initially then switch to the right door, but only a 1/3 chance of picking the right door initially then switching to a wrong door.

posts.title: Go to different discussion?
posts.body: Can we attend a discussion we're not registered for and mark the section we normally attend to get attendance points?

comments.comment: Yes, and you can find the schedules of different sections on piazza.

posts.title: CS 237 curve?
posts.body: Are there any curves in CS 237?

comments.comment: I've never taken a CS course that didnâ€™t curve.
